data.title: Steve Reich
data.meta_description: Explore the Red Bull Music Academy archive, tracing the global music institutionâs more than 20-year history
data.text:
Emma Warren

Weâve had Grammy-winners here before and weâve had legends here at the Red Bull Music Academy, but I donât think weâve ever had a Nobel Prize-winner, let alone a Nobel Prize-winner who also won a Pulitzer Prize.

Steve Reich

Pulitzer Prize. They donât give Nobels for music, you have to be in science or peace. [laughs]

Emma Warren

Iâll rephrase that then; weâve never had a Pulitzer Prize-winner. Steve Reich is an American composer, who started off working with tape loops and recorded speech, and made music youâll be familiar with, things like Drumming and Music for 18 Musicians. Obviously, that was just the beginning, because thereâs been a whole lot of music since then. This interview wonât be definitive â we only have an hour or so â but weâre going to make sure thereâs lots of time for you to ask questions afterwards. Iâm sure youâll have questions, so please make sure you hold them in your head and have them ready for us at the end. So, I think we should say a very big, warm welcome to Mr Steve Reich. [applause]

Thereâs a lovely quote at the end of Alex Rossâ book The Rest Is Noise, where he quotes Debussy, âThe job of the composer is to point the way to this imaginary country, essentially the place which was off the map.â Can you tell us how far off the map you were when you started making music?

Steve Reich

Never thought of it that way. [laughs] As a kid I took piano lessons and when I was 14, for the first time, I heard The Rite of Spring, 4th Brandenburg Concerto, and be-bop, Charlie Parker, Miles Davis, drummer Kenny Clarke. I had a friend who was a better piano player than me, and he said we need to form a band, we need a drummer. I said, âIâm it.â So I began studying drums at 14 with Roland Koloff, who became the timpanist with the New York Philharmonic, but he was also playing a local movie house with glow-in-the-dark sticks at midnight. He had a double life. This was back in 1950.

Emma Warren

Glow-in-the-dark sticks?

Steve Reich

Yes, youâd play your Gene Krupa drum solos with glow-in-the-dark sticks in a dark movie house. This was a trip in the 1950s. In any event, I didnât start with tape, tape didnât exist. When I was in high school, someone said, âHey, thereâs a tape recorder.â âWhatâs that?â âWell, you can actually record something into it.â It was basically when the American Army went into Germany after the war, they discovered the Germans had built tape recorders. The first recorder that I saw was called Wollensak, and thatâs what I used when I did Itâs Gonna Rain.

Emma Warren

Now, when you were growing up in the early days, you talk about encountering this tape recorder. It was very unusual for people to own machines â there obviously were machines in the world, but it was unusual for people to own them. When you first came across this tape machine, what was your impression of it?

Steve Reich

It was cheap; you could buy it. Wollensak â and I think Revere too â were the first home machines. Radio stations obviously had them. I think in those days Ampex was the brand thatâs long since disappeared. At first, it was just a way of recording if youâre playing something or recording your voice or whatever. But I guess I started getting interested when I moved to San Francisco in 1961, â62. I was studying with Luciano Berio, the Italian composer, and what he was working on when I started working with him was a piece called Omaggio O Joyce, meaning James Joyce. His wife, Cathy Berberian, whoâs a really good singer, was reading bits of Joyce and he was cutting up the tapes into little pieces into phonemes, which is what the book is about anyway. This was very far-out, non-narrative type writing. Basically, you were hearing the sound of letters and not really focusing on their meaning. I thought it was interesting. Then he played us two pieces by Stockhausen. One was called Electronic Studies and the other was Gesang Der JÃ¼nglinge. And my ear just went [whistles and moves his hand quickly in a straight line] to Gesang Der JÃ¼nglinge. Why? Because there was a voice of a young kid and I began to realize Iâm not interested in electronics or synthesis. Still not interested. Couldnât care less. Itâs a marriage of convenience, but I donât like it. Iâm interested in really analog sound. And therefore when the sampler was invented I said, âThatâs for me.â Another thing that was in the air in the late â50s, early â60s, was tape loops. Raise your hand if you know what a tape loop is. [few hands go up] OK, when there was reel-to-reel tape, you could take a splicing block and splice the beginning to the end of a six-, seven-inch piece of tape. And the head assembly of these small tape recorders was small enough that you could fit the loop over the head assembly, press the âgoâ button and it would compress up against the head and play back. Youâd be recording at seven-and-a-half inches per second. Youâd get very unusual results that nobody had ever heard in the 1950s or â60s. At that time I also became aware of West African music, both by listening to recordings and by discovering a book called Studies in African Music, which was the first book of accurate scores of music from Ghana. I think you can find it online, actually. Google is going to steal everything, so I think they managed to get this far. Anybody here have any familiarity with musical notation? [some hands go up] Well, those of you who do, you will see basically divisions into subdivisions of 12, patterns in three beats, patterns in four beats, patterns in six beats, patterns in twelve beats. Whatâs strange is, you say, âWhereâs the downbeat, whereâs one?â Well, the rattle has it here, this drummer has it there. Thatâs from Mars, you know? Generally, when you listen to rock, youâre in four-four, everybody knows where one is. Hereâs a music where there is no one downbeat. There are multiple downbeats depending on the player, and they just feel it that way. Alright, when I was working with the multiple tape loops and hearing it, I said, âWhat have I got here? mechanised Africans.â [laughs]

Emma Warren

Thereâs so much to talk about in there when you went to Ghana and it was different from what youâd read about, and also what you read at university and also what youexperienced outside of that. But I think we should bring it back for a minute to the piece of music weâre going to play and talk about. Can you tell us what we are going to listen to?

Steve Reich

OK, sheâs right. Itâs Gonna Rain. In 1964 a friend whose name I canât remember, who was going to make films and never did, said, âI have heard the most amazing black Pentecostal preacher in Union Square in San Francisco. Youâve got to record him.â I had a Ewer portable tape recorder and an Electrovoice cheap shotgun mic. So I went down on the Sunday, and sure enough there was this guy who called himself Brother Walter. He was preaching about the flood of Noah in the Bible, which is about the end of the world. This is 1964. In 1963 was the Cuban Missile Crisis. Anybody know what that is? Khrushchev, the Russian leader, had sent over nuclear missiles on a boat for installation in Cuba. John F. Kennedy said, âIf you do that weâre going to bomb Moscow with hydrogen bombs.â So everybody was kind of concerned; the ships kept going and there was a blockade around Cuba and many of us â me included â felt the clock was ticking. We could just turn into so much radioactive smoke. Fortunately, Khrushchev backed down, so donât think about JFK as a peace-loving wimp, forget it. And it passed. But it made a mark in every human being who was alive then. So a year later, Iâm in Union Square and this preacher is laying it down about the end of the world. Itâs not abstract. Itâs not abstract at all. So Iâm going to play the whole first movement, which is about six or seven minutes. The whole piece is about 17 minutes. Then Iâll explain how I made it. Some of it will be very clear to you, some will be a bit weird. But it turns out I was actually doing some DJing. I was playing a preamp. So Iâm going to play it, then Iâm going to sit in the back because itâs weird to just watch you (stands up and sits down in the back of the room).

(music: Steve Reich â âItâs Gonna Rainâ / applause)

Emma Warren

So you come back from Union Square with your recording. How do you take it from how it sounded to that?

Steve Reich

Good question. First of all, Iâm gonna ask you, when you hear Itâs Gonna Rain, first you hear in the background wha-wha-wha-wha. Itâs a drummer, right? But itâs not a drummer. So what was it? Any guesses? [inaudible from participant] Yeah! Somebody cheated. [laughs] The moment I recorded it, and he said, âItâs gonna rain,â a pigeon took off. And when you looped it, pigeon drummer. Didnât have to pay him extra, he wasnât doubling. [laughs] So thatâs just there. The piece starts in mono and you hear the source material. You think, ah, this is some really strong black preacher laying it down about Noah. And then you hear this funny âitâs-go-itâs-go-itâs-go-rai-rai-rain.â Whatâs happening is, Iâve got a stereo loop and one track is âitâs gonna rainâ and on another track is âitâs gonna rain,â but theyâre offset, so âitâs gonnaâ is on top of ârainâ and ârainâ is on top of âitâs gonna.â So, if I go back in the tempo of the loop, I get âitâs gonna, itâs gonna, itâs gonna...â But what if I go a little faster than the tempo of the loop itself? Then Iâm going to start phasing ahead, and thatâs what you heard. There are two cycles of that. Youâre moving ahead because your hand... I had a weird preamp, it was one of these preamps that had a lot of controls; who needs them? But it turned out there was this mono-A, mono-B. So you could have all of the A track coming out of both tracks, or all of the B coming out of both tracks. I was just going back and forth between mono-A, mono-B. Start off in rhythm, and gradually phase ahead of the tape myself going from mono to mono, mono to mono. Finally, after two cycles of that, you get âitâs gonna, itâs gonna...â and youâre back in the mono loop coming out of both channels. Then, all of a sudden, you hear a change in quality. What is it? It goes into stereo. You feel it, like something weirdâs happening. You know exactly what it is thatâs happening. Then, slowly, I think itâs the left-hand side begins to go faster. Why? I tried to cut the loops as perfectly as I can, but you know, what does that mean? Thereâs gonna be some fractional difference between them, right? Maybe thereâs a bit of dirt on one of the motors. These arenât like the kind of motors we have today, theyâre motors with a certain amount of drift to them. So one channel begins to slip ahead of the other. Now, the effect of one sound coming in sooner than the other will give you the sense of direction location. You will hear it coming from the side that is coming in first. If youâre listening to the piece with headphones, it feels like this â the sound comes over your left shoulder, slides down your arm, off and away. Itâs creepy, it goes across the room. And then you hear reverberation, when it gets far enough apart. But when itâs really close together â and I suppose you could do this digitally â you have slight differences in what comes in first. This was established in Bell Labs years ago. Someone asked how people know where voices are coming from, where are they? Well, it gets to one ear sooner than the other. Or we just look in that direction. So this is that phenomena happening in that piece. Then it very slowly goes around from unison, out of phase, pigeon drummer, whole nine yards, back into unison, then âitâs gonna rainâ after a while. Now, the second movement gets very spooky and very far out and I felt very paranoid, but given what was going on in the world, maybe it wasnât. I wonât go through that, but if youâre interested, itâs quite a trip. Itâs basically where heâs in the Ark and locks the door. People knocked and the skin came off their hand, the door was sealed by the hand of God. It is the end of the world, itâs a portrayal in sound of the end of the world. Yes, I was in a bad state of mind at the time.

Emma Warren

How did the music sound to you at the time and how was it seen by people you played it to and people who heard it?

Steve Reich

Well, the first question I can answer and the second question they can answer. When I did the first part there was no question it felt incredibly invigorating, wow, what energy and this guyâs fantastic. And the treatment of the voice and the voice itself are hand in glove. I think that thatâs a general principle that can be applied to most anything youâre doing. If the musical material â whether itâs notes or sampled material â and what youâre doing with it reinforce each other, then youâre probably on the right track. This is a very intuitive thing and there are no rules, but thereâs a gut feeling about it. And different material wants different technical treatment. As to how it affects people, pass the mic around and find out.

Emma Warren

I suppose what Iâm more interested in is how it was perceived by people at the time. So, when people heard it, what did they make of it?

Steve Reich

First of all, nobody was giving me interviews in London. I was driving a cab in San Francisco. I was just out of graduate school and I decided I wasnât going to teach. So I was a cab driver and one day I got really zonked out. I was going about five miles an hour and, you know, you canât have any problems because youâve got your foot on the brake and youâre only inching forward; but I inched right into the back of somebody. So then I ended up working at the post office. [laughs] A few people came over the house and said, âMan thatâs far out!â OK, thatâs true. Then it was played at the San Francisco Tape Music Center and people said, âOh, wow.â But there were maybe only about 75 people there. And the piece didnât really have an audience. It came out on a Columbia Masterworks record in 1969, a year and half after Come Out was released on Columbia, and that really got a lot of attention. So this piece was in the shadow of that first piece.

Emma Warren

I want to ask you about the Tape Center we just talked about. I know you werenât really involved, you did present your work there. You just talked about your day job.

Steve Reich

Night job.

Emma Warren

Post office, night job, day job, whatever. But a lot of people here are in similar positions, having to do day jobs until they reach that point where they can bridge into a full-time music career. What was the benefit for you of having that day job and how did you use that to feed your music?

Steve Reich

Necessity is the mother of invention. I had an MA in music and I couldâve pursued it, applying to university x, y and z, teaching harmony and theory in Nebraska. [laughs] Or some major city perhaps. But I just felt up to there with the academic world. I just felt I had a teacher earlier on I admired in New York. He did the arrangements for Thelonious Monkâs concerts. He got asked to join the Juilliard faculty in New York and I saw his shoulders sag. I think the academic career can beâ¦ Although who knows, maybe that will work for some of you. Iâm sure there are universities here in the UK that are starting to open recording labs and youâll get your undergraduate degree. âWhat did you read?â âI read DJ." [laughs] You know? Anything can be turned into academic trash, no question about it. Youâre not exempt. In my time it was composers. I suppose, if you went through your W9 forms, your tax return forms, every composer in America, somewhere between 90-95 percent of them would be at universities. Iâm not looking down my nose at them. Itâs really the job thatâs most open to you, but I felt this myth, well, you teach during the day and the evening is so and so. But thereâs a certain amount of energy that goes into teaching people and if you donât give them that energy, then youâre immoral. And if you do give them that energy, then youâre wiped out. Because thereâs only so much energy one person has. So Iâd rather drive a cab. I bugged the cab and I made a tape piece. I stopped the cab and played shows with the San Francisco Mime Troupe with Phil Lesh, who became the bass player for the Grateful Dead. I had a good time driving a cab. And I wasnât invested in it, you know what I mean? I could make music, take time off to play a show. It really fit me, and I was making more money than most assistant professors too. [laughs]

Emma Warren

So youâre in a cab, interacting with street culture in a very direct way. The sound of the streets and that street culture is very present in a recurring way throughout your career. So you think that street life was influential for you musically?

Steve Reich

Well, you could say I did City Life because I drove a cab in San Francisco. I donât know how true that would be. Iâm a native New Yorker, as you can probably tell. I think all music comes from a time and place. The Beatles come from â60s England, Kurt Weill comes from Weimar Republic in Germany, the baroque period. Bach comes from Eastern Germany. I come from New York and the West Coast in the 1960s and â70s. The composers we know and love I think give honest expression to that. Not by trying to write the great American piece. Forget that. You just are who you are. And if youâre honest about who you are, then that music will bear evidence to the honesty of your situation, no matter what it is. What you guys are doing right now is evidence of whatâs going on in the world. How well you do it will determine how long and how much interest there is in it. Because musical quality doesnât change. There was this story about George Gershwin meeting Alban Berg, who was a friend of Schoenbergâs. Gershwin was a bit nervous and Berg could tell that, so he said, âMr. Gershwin, music is music.â Thatâs the kind of truth that stays the case. Sorry, Iâm losing my train of thought there.

Emma Warren

No, it was a fantastic thought. One thing Iâm interested in is you as a young man being obsessed by Coltrane. I understand you went to see him 50 times or more.

Steve Reich

I didnât count but it was a lot.

Emma Warren

Where did you see him and how deep was your connection to the music? Paint us a picture.

Steve Reich

I saw him a lot when I was a junior in New York at the Five Spot. Saw him in San Francisco at the Jazz Workshop. Once saw him there with Eric Dolphy. Eric Dolphy was responsible for the bass clarinets in Music For 18 Musicians. I brought that in, we can talk about that briefly. Why was I interested and why were so many other people â Terry Riley, La Monte Young? Anybody with a pair of ears should listen to Coltrane. I highly recommend an album called Africa / Brass. Not necessarily the most famous, but for musicians in terms of an extreme form. Itâs about half and hour long and itâs got a very big band and Eric Dolphy did the arrangements. I think there are French horns playing like elephants coming through the jungle. But whatâs interesting is that the whole 30 minutes are in E. You know how jazz men talk about the changes? âWhatâs the change?â âE.â âNo, no, no, whatâs the changes?â âE!â E for half an hour. âWait a minute, come on, E for half an hour?â Well, itâs built on the low E of the double bass, played by Jimmy Garrison. Youâd say, âNo, itâs stupid. Thatâs too boring.â But itâs not. Itâs definitely not boring. Why? Whatâs going on to compensate for the lack of harmonic movement? Now of course, you live in a time when weâve had a lot of water under the bridge. But Iâm talking 1963, â64, â65. Thereâs incredible melodic invention, sometimes Coltraneâs playing gorgeous melodies, sometimes heâs screaming noise through the horn. Sometimes these elephant glissandos going on, which are basically French horns playing glissandos, scored by Eric Dolphy, who was a great musician and one of the great alto sax players and a very schooled musician as well. And two drummers, Elvin Jones being one of the most inventive jazz drummers who ever lived. And I think Rashied Ali was the other drummer. So youâve got an incredible amount of rhythmic complexity, temporal variety and melodic invention. And they more than compensate for the harmonic consistency. As a matter of fact, thereâs a tension because it doesnât change. At the same period of time there was a Motown tune by Junior Walker, saxophone player back in Detroit, called âShotgun.â The bassline was like this... [imitates bassline] And because it didnât change, youâre waiting for this thing [to happen], but it didnât. In America in the mid-â60s, there was something in the air about harmonic stasis. We were hearing Ravi Shankar coming in from India; we were hearing Balinese music; we were hearing African drumming; we were hearing John Coltrane; we were hearing stuff coming in from Junior Walker and Motown. Bob Dylan, âAinât gonna work on Maggieâs farm no more.â Alot of stuff on that first album, thereâs a lot of the one chord. A little turn around on four and five and right back on one. And that incredible non-, but wonderful, voice that he has. So there was this thing in the air coming in from various sources outside of the West, from jazz, from popular music, which was pointing in this direction. And without that I never wouldâve done what Iâve done, Riley would never have written In C, etc., etc. Things come from a certain time and a certain place. If this hardware werenât around [gestures at the turntable], you would be doing something else. We interact with whatâs around us. Thatâs, in a sense, folk music. What you guys are doing is basically now a kind of folk music, which, as I understand, has already been codified and is being studied and multiplied. But it spontaneously arose in the culture and now many, many people are developing it. Iâve always seen pop music as the folk music of our time. Dylanâs plugging in was the end of that old Woody Guthrie folk music and the beginning of firmly establishing rock music as the folk music of our culture, and now the further developments thereof. And when you look in the window of a music store, what do you see? You see electronics, and thatâs the folk instruments of our time. Thatâs how I see it.

Emma Warren

If weâre staying in New York around this time, what did the city sound like? So much of your music is based on the way you hear the environment around you. How did it sound?

Steve Reich

Noisy. I used to walk around with ear-plugs. Shall I play some of City Life? I felt after Itâs Gonna Rain and another tape piece called Come Out, this was a fantastic technique, this phasing idea. Tapes can do it, windshield wipers on a bus can do it, bells on a railway crossing can do it, but you canât do it and I canât do it. Finally I said, âIâm the second tape recorder.â And I made a tape loop of a piano pattern, sat down with it, closed my eyes and I just got as slowly ahead of it as I could. And this piece Piano Phase came out, which eventually could be done by two pianos. And it is done by two pianos and thereâs a recording of that here. I thought Iâd play you that.

Emma Warren

Letâs do that, because I wanted to ask you about that. I read something where you said that when you did that, you needed to listen in a way youâd never listened before. Is it possible to improve or radically alter the way you listen through practice?

Steve Reich

Oh, absolutely. Can someone come up here and moveâ¦ I have no idea what all this [equipment] is. We were on track four and we need to go to track two. Can you do that?

(music: Steve Reich â âPiano Phaseâ / applause)

Thatâs Nurit Tilles and Edmund Neimann playing two pianos. Now, how do you play that piece? First of all, you memorize the notes because theyâre obviously pretty easy. Put notation on the side, one person starts, the other closes their eyes probably and gets in unison. And then one maybe nods to the other person, like, âOK, Iâm gonna try and move now.â And then tries to slide ahead as slowly as they can against the other player. The other player has got the easy part? I donât think so. I usually do the phasing, I have high metabolism. The hard part is staying put. Itâs like a vacuum cleaner. The tempoâs going up and youâve got to say, âNo, Iâm not going with it. Iâm going to let them pass me.â Thereâs like a physical force pulling you, but you want to stay in the irrational, irrational relationship, and if you do that right you get this kind of spinning around, and then finally it gels. And that's what you just heard too. And eventually it comes around and back in unison the way Itâs Gonna Rain did. But for me this was, âLook ma, no tape!â [laughter] So it opened the floodgates to working with instruments. Because I was a composer, I didnât want to be the little old tape-maker. Again, no casting aspersions on people making laptop music, everything has its place. But me, at that time, thatâs how I felt.

Emma Warren

How difficult â or how interesting â did you find that transition between machine and musician?

Steve Reich

At first I was like, âIâm trapped, what have I done? I canât leave this thing, I canât do it live.â But I finally said, well letâs try it. I could do it against tape, then a friend and I could do it together and then other people started doing it. I felt liberated, I felt exhilarated, I felt the door had opened. That led to Drumming. If you want to go Queen Elizabethâ¦ Well, itâs sold out, but those of you who are there tonight will hear Drumming, which was the last piece to use the phasing technique, in 1971. Never used it since. Why? Because it is a weird technique. If you go to a conventional music school anywhere in the Western world, or Japan or anywhere else, they will not teach you how to phase â except some teacher whoâs into my music may teach you how to do that. The percussionist will do it, but there are other ways of getting what is calledâ¦ like, "Row, Row, Row Your Boat," a canon or a round. Thatâs basically whatâs going on here. Thatâs whatâs going on in Itâs Gonna Rain â itâs one sound against itself. Thatâs a canon; it can be from the 13th century, it can be Johann Sebastian Bach, it can be Bela BartÃ³k, it can be Steve Reich. Itâs one thing against itself rhythmically displaced. So this is that principle. But the odd part is that usually itâs like, ârow, row, row your boat gently down the streamâ and on âmerrily,â you come in with ârow.â Thatâs the way it is. OK, thatâs one way that it is. The way it is here is that people come in together and irrationally slide ahead. So in a sense, itâs kind of a footnote to the history of imitative counterpoint or round or canon in the Western world. Now this is not something you will find in Africa or Bali or anywhere else, itâs something quite unique to our civilisation. Why? Because the idea came from a machine. Now, this is one of the things I want to get across. We live in a time whereâs itâs possible to get ideas for music from machines and get ideas for computer music from live music, that are perfectly valid and will work if you get it right. That to me is a kind of solution to anyone who looks at people who make electronic music as a whole bunch of robots. That whole syndrome is locked on the idea that youâve got your minds closed to anything thatâs to do with live music, which would be an unfortunate situation to be in. But itâs the same thing with people who are into live music. Now, I think everybody within the culture is open to all music. This is something pretty much well understood by all of you. But for me, it was a big deal because this was not the case. Just a few people beginning to see that these are permeable divisions. This is a very, very clear example of that, just taking it right from the tape and putting it right into instruments.

Emma Warren

I wanted to ask you something about Drumming. I understand the Steve Reich and Musicians, the ensemble, when you gave them the piece you wouldnât give them notation; you taught it to them and made them learn it. So they had to feel the music and learn it without seeing it. Now a lot of people here are using programs where you almost canât avoid seeing the music because itâs there in front of you. What are the benefits of learning the music without seeing it?
